importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The film's daily screenings were nearly discontinued in 2015 due to declining attendance, but public backlash from fans led to the decision being reversed, highlighting its deep cultural resonance and audience loyalty.
The film Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge was released on October 20, 1995, marking the beginning of its long-standing cultural and cinematic legacy in India.
The 30th anniversary of the film's daily screenings at the Maratha Mandir theatre in Mumbai is being celebrated, underscoring its enduring popularity and relevance in contemporary Indian society.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 30-year period from 1995 to 2025 reflects the sustained cultural influence of the film, demonstrating how a single Bollywood romance has remained a central part of Indian cinematic and social life.

keyTakeAways: Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ) is India’s longest-running film, with continuous daily screenings at Maratha Mandir theatre in Mumbai for 30 years.
The film redefined modern Hindi romance by portraying a love story that defied tradition and emphasized emotional commitment over social expectations.
It continues to draw large crowds, including university students and young couples, with Sunday audiences reaching around 500 people.
Audiences respond emotionally to the film’s climax, especially the scene where the father lets his daughter go, creating a 'goosebump moment'.
The film has become a cultural monument, resonating with younger generations who view it as a counterpoint to modern transactional relationships.
Its endurance has been challenged in 2015 when screenings were nearly discontinued, but fan backlash revived the practice.
The film has influenced real-life relationships, with couples citing it as a key moment during their dating or marriage planning.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Maratha Mandir theatre in Mumbai is celebrating 30 years of daily screenings of the iconic Bollywood romance film Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ), which premiered in 1995 and has become India’s longest-running film. The film, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, redefined modern Indian romance by portraying a love story that defied tradition and emphasized emotional commitment. Despite near-discontinuation in 2015 due to declining attendance, public backlash led to its revival. The film continues to draw large crowds, particularly among young couples and students, with Sunday attendance reaching 500. Audiences often react emotionally to its climax, where the father lets his daughter go, creating a shared 'goosebump' moment. The film remains relevant today as a cultural monument that reflects the ongoing tension between traditional and modern values, with younger viewers citing it as a counterpoint to transactional relationships. Some couples even credit the film with influencing their own love stories, and it has become a symbol of enduring cinematic and emotional legacy in India.
title: Iconic Bollywood romance marks 30 years of nonstop run at Mumbai theatre
